Romeo and Juliet.Quote: From forth the fatal loins of these two foes...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: In each of the words from, forth, and fatal, the first letter is f. This is alliteration, the repetition of the initial letter in two or more words.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Look at the first letters. There are a lot of "f"s at the beginning of words.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
...dignity

...

...mutiny
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: In both dignity and mutiny, the vowels sound similar, but they are not perfect rhymes.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Try saying these out loud. How do the vowels sound in each? Do they rhyme, or is it not quite a rhyme?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Doth with their death...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: In death and doth, there are repeated consonant sounds (d - th). In this case, it could be either a case of alliteration, as the initial letters are the same, or consonance, as the final consonants agree even as the vowels do not.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Say the first and last words out loud one after the other. What's similar? What's different?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
The which, if you with patient ears attend,

What here shall miss, our toil shall strive to mend.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: At the end of many acts, Shakespeare ends them with a couplet: two lines, rhyming with the pattern aa (here, attend/mend).
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Check out the last words. How do they sound?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Therefore if thou art moved thou runn'st...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Much like conjunctions, when there is an apostrophe in the place of a vowel or syllable, something has been removed. Here, thou runnestbecomes shortened to thou runn'st. Because the shortening is one word, it is a syncope rather than an elision. Syncope is often confused with elision, whose shortening is between two words rather than one.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Why is there an apostrophe in this passage? What purpose does it serve?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: I... will thrust his maids to the wall...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Thrust has sexual meanings when used in this context, suggested by the vulgar wordplay between the two servants. This is connotation - meaning beyond the dictionary definition.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: What does thrust mean? How is it used? Does this have a meaning beyond simply the act of thrusting?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: That quench the fire of your pernicious rage...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The rage between the houses is being compared to fire, using a metaphor to create imagery.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Is rage fiery? What does that make you think of?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Women, being

the weaker vessels...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: In this context, it is a biblical reference to 1 Peter 3:7, Husbands, in the same way be considerate as you live with your wives, and treat them with respect as the weaker partner.... Don't sweat it if you don't know this though. Allusions will frequently refer to more famous historical/literary figures.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: This is an obscure reference to a well-known text, the Bible.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: The fiery Tybalt with his sword prepared...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Fiery Tybaltis used to describe Tybalt's lack of temper, and is used throughout the play. This is an epithet - an adjective or phrase highlighting a characteristic of a person or thing.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: What is Tybalt's personality like? How do characters refer to him in the play?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
...The fiery sun

Peered forth the golden window of the east...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The sun is turned into a more humanlike figure when it is described as peering, which is what personification is.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Can suns really peer?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: The shady curtains from Aurora's bed...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Aurora was the Greek goddess of dawn. Here, Shakespeare makes a reference to a literary figure - allusion.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Is Aurora a character in the play? (Hint: she isn't.) Why is she mentioned here?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Alas that love, whose view is muffled still,

Should without eyes see pathways to his will!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Sight is being used by Shakespeare in these two lines - first with blindness (whose view is muffled) and then sight (see pathways to his will). This is an example of juxtaposition. This is not an antithesis, since there is no similar grammatical structure.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: There are opposite ideas expressed in here.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: O brawling love, o loving hate!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo addresses ideas of hateful love and loving hate - two oppositional ideas. This is an oxymoron. This is not an apostrophe, because Romeo is not speaking to these ideas.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Does anything seem off about what words Romeo chooses to use to describe each of the nouns?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: A sea nourished with loving tears...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This imagery appeals to your five senses. A sea of loving tears...Imagine the salty sea, the sound of the waves crashing on the shore, the deep blue depths... This is also a metaphor; it compares loving tears to a sea.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: What do you see when you hear this?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: A fire sparking in lovers' eyes...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is both imagery and a metaphor.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Are there really fires in lovers' eyes?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: She hath Dian's wit...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Dian, the Roman goddess of hunting and maidenhood, did not marry. This is a reference to Roman mythology.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Who is Dian? She is a character not originally from this play.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
She hath forsworn to love, and in that vow

Do I live dead, that live to tell it now.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The line break forces a pause between an otherwise uninterrupted sentence (here, in that vow / do I live dead). A caesura, by contrast, would have both on the same line but punctuation splitting the sentence.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Why is there a line break? What does this serve?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
When well-appareled April on the heel

Of limping winter treads...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: April is not a person. It is a month. Yet here, Shakespeare describes it has well-appareled... on the heel- making it seem like a human being.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Is April a person?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she;
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Earth is not a person, yet it can swallow. This is personification - attributing human attributes and actions to a non-human thing.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Can Earth swallow things?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: God gi' good e'en.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The words are shortened to facilitate reading - the definition of elision. This is not syncope, as the removal affects how two words connect (gi' good) rather than just how one word sounds.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Why is there an apostrophe in the sentence?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Why, [Paris is] a man of wax.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Juliet is comparing Paris to a man of wax, i.e. a perfect man that an artist would carve out of wax. This is an example of metaphor; there are no comparators such as likeor as.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Is Paris really a man of wax? What does that mean?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Read o'er this volume of young Paris' face,

and find delight writ there with beauty's pen.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Lady Capulet compares Paris to a book in an extended metaphor.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: What is Paris being compared to here?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
You have dancing shoes

with nimble soles. I have a soul of lead...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: By using the words solesand soulstogether, Shakespeare makes a pun with the homophony of the two words.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Soles souls?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: [Love] pricks like thorn.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Shakespeare compares love to a thorn; here, the comparison uses a comparator, like. This makes it a simile.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: There's a comparison between love and thorn...

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Here are the beetle brows shall blush for me.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The repeated "b" in "beetle" "brows" and "blush" make alliteration.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Look at the first letter of some of the words. What do they have in common?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: The game was ne'er so fair...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The omitted v in nevermakes this a syncope, as the omission only affects one word. Not be confused with elision, which would involve at least two words.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: What is the purpose of the apostrophe?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Her collars of moonshine's wat'ry beams...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Here, Shakespeare compares Queen Mab's collars to moonshine's watery beams; this is a metaphor as well as a syncope. Shakespeare omits the ein watery.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Notice the apostrophe in the sentence, as well as how collars are being compared.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
I talk of dreams,

Which are the children of an idle brain...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Dreams are not children, because they are not people. Here, Shakespeare personifies them by making them the children of an idle brain.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Are dreams children?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
...who woos

Even now the frozen bosom...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The line break serves to emphasize the beginning of the next line - the frozen boso of the North. This is enjambement - when a sentence does not finish on one line but wraps to the next.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Does the line break feel natural to you? Why would Shakespeare put it there?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
I fear too early...

...

some vile forfeit of untimely death.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo's line here foreshadows his death at the end of the play.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Romeo is speaking. What does he do at the end of the play? Why is he speaking about death here?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Ah, my mistresses, which of you all

Will now deny to dance? She that makes dainty...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is an example of both enjambement (Which of you all / Will now...) as the sentence wraps to the next line, but also a caesura (Will now deny to dance? She that makes dainty...) as the sentence ends with a question mark in the middle of the line.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: What's with the line breaks and question marks?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Am I the master here or you? Go to.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The question mark here breaks in the middle of one line. This is an example of caesura.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: This quote is entirely on one line. Why is there punctuation in the middle of the one line?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Is she a Capulet?

O dear account! My life is my foe's debt.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo speaks directly to the audience, breaking the fourth wall. This line is not heard by anybody on stage other than himself. Both of these are characteristics of an aside.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Romeo says these lines to the audience, and nobody else hears him.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: My only love sprung from my only hate!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Juliet speaks of her only lovearising from her only hate; these two oppositional words create a paradox. How can love come from hate?
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Love and hate. Two opposites, yet one creates the other for Juliet. It seems like it should be impossible.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: As rich as a jewel in Ethiop's ear...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo compares Juliet's beauty to a jewel upon a dark background (a jewel on Ethiop's ear, i.e. a jewel on a black person). Because he uses comparators, this is a simile.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: How is Romeo phrasing this comparison? Does it use comparison words or is it implicit?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Young affection gapes to be his heir.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Shakespeare gives young affectiona desire, a human attribute. The attribution of human passions (gapingto be his heir) is specifically a form of pathetic fallacy, and more generally also personification.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Is young affectiona person? How does it gapeto be another's heir?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: She steal love's bait from fearful hooks.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Love is being compared to bait, and Juliet's actions are compared to stealingthe baitfrom featful hooks. These comparisons are done implicitly.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Is there a comparison being done here? How, if there is one, is it done?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: King Cophetua refers to a story of an African king who did not love anybody until he saw a beggar-maid without clothing on the street. He offered her clothing and vowed to marry her or commit suicide. At the end, they lived a peaceful life and were well loved by their people. Mercutio reference this story (an allusion) while speaking to Romeo.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Is King Cophetua a part of the story of a reference to some other work?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: It is the East, and Juliet is the sun.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo compares Juliet to the rising sun.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Is Juliet really a sun? Why does Romeo compare her to one?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Arise, fair sun, and kill the envious moon...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo is speaking to the sun, an absent entity. This is an example of personification, or apostrophe. There is also juxtaposition in terms of "fair" and "envious", as well as "sun" and "moon"
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Whom is Romeo talking to?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: But soft, what light through yonder window breaks?
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The combination of soft consonants (w in whatand window, y in yonder, as well as the long vowels (in sOft, yOnder) both contribute to a melodious and soft line. This is a more difficult literary device to pick out; try and look out for the soft consonants and long vowels to spot it!
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Try saying this one aloud and see how it sounds. Is it pleasant? Does it sound painful?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
[In reference to Juliet] As glorious to this night, being o'er my head,

as a wingèd messenger of heaven...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Juliet is not really *that* pretty, although she may be to Romeo. This is both an example of simile as well as hyperobole.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: When Romeo says this, he is clearly blowing Juliet's beauty a bit out of proportion.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
By love, that first did prompt me to inquire.

He lent me counsel, and I lent him eyes.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Here, Romeo casts love as his guide; he makes love out to be a person, who guides him towards finding Juliet. This gives love, a non-human entity, human desires - pathetic fallacy and personification.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: In what way does Romeo refer to love in this passage?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
At lovers' perjuries,

They say, Jove laughs.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: In this passage, a reference to the Roman god Jupiter is made (allusion) as well as a line split (enjambement).
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Who is Jove? She is not a character in this play.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
And not impute this yielding to light love,

Which the dark night hath so discovered.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Light and dark are opposites, played against each other for dramatic effect. This is juxtaposition.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Look at the contrast between "light love" and "dark night". These words are used next to each other to increase their effect on the audience. What is this literary device called?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
[This contract] is too rash...

Too like the lightning.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Juliet in this passage compares this contract to lightning, using a comparison word. This is an example of simile.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: This is a comparison, with the word "like", so it's not a metaphor. What's the other type of comparison?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Ere one can say "it lightens". Sweet, good night.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The period in the middle of the passage is a caesura (from Latin, caedere, to break). Think of cease or "casser" - it breaks the flow of the sentence.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: This passage is entirely on one line, yet there is a period in the middle of it. What is this type of interruption called?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Love toward love goes as schoolboys from their books,

But love from love, toward school with heavy looks.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Juliet compares love to school, but it's not a metaphor. To Juliet, love is an unfamiliar concept that she likens to a familiar concept (i.e. schoolboys). What is this called?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: The grey-eyed morn smiles on the frowning night...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This passage has pathetic fallacy, juxtaposition, and personification. The "morn" and "night" are ascribed human traits ("grey-eyed", "smiling", "frowning"), making it personification, and human emotions (the connotation of "smiling" and "frowning"), making it pathetic fallacy. There is also juxtaposition in terms of morning and night, as well as smiling and frowning.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Especially for weather, when it's treated as a person, it's a specific type of personification. What is this?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: The day to cheer and night's dank dew to dry...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This quote has a lot of "d"s at the beginning of the word (e.g. "day", "dank", "dew", "dry"). This is alliteration.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Look at the first letters of these words. Are there repeated conconants?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
The earth that's nature's mother is her tomb;

What is her burying grave, that is her womb...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Friar Lawrence speaks of a "tomb" (implying death), but also of a "womb" (implying birth). These contrasting ideas expressing the circle of life have similar structure, creating antithesis. Speaking of nature has having a "mother" also personifies it.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Look at the rhyming words. Do their ideas contrast? Why are they put so closely to each other?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Holy Saint Francis, what a change is here!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Saint Francis was a Roman Catholic preacher who lived in the 13th century in Italy. I didn't know that either. But when you see a character or person who isn't part of the story being mentioned, it's very likely an allusion.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Saint Francis is not a character in this story. Why is he included in this quote?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: ...what a deal of brine...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: "Brine" is used in place of tears, and is metonymy. This is not synecdoche because brine is not a part of tears.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: "Brine" refers to salt water, and in this case, represents tears. This word is used in place of another.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Friar Lawrence as a character
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The "wise old man" archetype is used in Romeo and Juliet in the form of Friar Lawrence. This is an example of a stock character, or type character.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Friar Lawrence gives counsel to Romeo. He plays the part of a "wise old man". What type of character is he?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Alas, poor Romeo, he is already dead, stabbed...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Mercutio exaggerates the state that Romeo is in right now (he's not actually dead). This is hyperbole.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: At this point in the play, Romeo is not actually dead yet. The characters are exaggerating.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Petrarch... Laura... Dido... Cleopatra... Helen... Hero...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: These references are to other fictional characters that have demonstrated great love: an allusion.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: All of these women are fictional; they are reference to other works and couples. What type of literary device is this?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
MERCUTIO: Nay, I am the very pink of courtesy.

Romeo: "Pink" for flower.

Well then, my pump is well flowered.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is a pay of words, a pun.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: The word pink and flower have many meanings and they are used for comedic effect.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Bitter and sweet are opposites, and usually do not go together. This is an example of oxymoron.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: What do bitter and sweet taste like? They are opposites of each other, yet here, Mercutio descibes the "sweeting" as "bitter".

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: For her fans's the fairer face.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is an alliteration, with the "f"s at the beginning of "for", "fan", "fairer", and "face".
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Look at the first letter of these words. They are all "F"s. What does that mean?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: She would be as swift in motion as a ball.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: A simile because it uses comparison words.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Juliet is compararing, with the structure "as... as...". What type of comparison is this?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Hie to high fortune!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is a pun due to the play on words between "hie" and "high".
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: There is a similarity in sound between "hie" and "high", even though they mean different things. Even though this is not humourous, this is considered...

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: These violent delights have violent ends.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This sentence is an example of many literary devices. First, antithesis, by putting opposing ideas into a similar grammatical structure ("violent delights" vs "violent ends"). This is also thus juxtaposition, where "delights" and "ends" are put very close together to play off each other and increase the dramatic effect of the other. Finally, it is also foreshadowing, as it tells the audience how the love story between Romeo and Juliet will end.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Notice the similar structure between "violent delights" and "violent ends". However, these have opposite meanings.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: ...die, like fire and powder...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This sentence is a simile.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Friar Lawrence is comparing fast love to "fire and powder", using a comparison word.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Oh Juliet, if the measure of thy joy

Be heaped like mine...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This excerpt is an example of enjambement, where the sentence continues on the next line. Not to be confused with caesura, which is when a sentence ends in the middle of one line.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: There is a line break between "joy" and "Be", yet the sentence is not finished.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Thy head is as full of quarrels as an egg is full of meat...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Mercutio is comparing Benvolio's short-temperedness to an egg full of meat, using the strucutre "as... as...". These are comparison words.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Good e'en.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Because the abbreviation is all within one word, this is an example of syncope. Not to be confused with elision, which is abbreviation between two or more words to facilitate pronunciation.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Evening is shortened to "e'en" in this sentence. Evening is only one word.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Ay, ay, a scratch, a scratch.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Downplaying the mortal wound by calling it a scratch is an example of understatement.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Mercutio is literally bleeding out on the streets, yet he says that his wound is only "a scratch, a scratch."

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Ask for me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Play on words? Dad joke? It's a pun!
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Mercutio knows that he will be dead tomorrow. This is a play on words with the word "grave" - a serious man, or a dead man.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: A villain that fights by the book of arithmetic!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is an example of metonymy, which is referring to something by another name. This is not to be confused with synechdoche, which is referring to the whole thing by one of its parts.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Mercutio is speaking about the fencing manual when he refers to it as "book of arithmetic". He substitutes the real name with something that is related. What is this called?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Brave Mercutio is dead.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: In the form adjective-name, "Brave Mercutio" is a good example of an epithet.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: "Brave Mercutio" describes how Mercutio acts, and is how Benvolio refers to him.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Here comes furious Tybalt yet again.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Another epithet in the form adjective-name - "furious Tybalt". Most epithets are easily recognizable with by this structure.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: "Furious Tybalt" describes Tybalt, and is how Benvolio refers to him.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Gallop apace, you fiery footed steeds.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is another example of an epithet - adjective-noun form. "Fiery-footed" is the adjective highlighting the speed of the horses, and "steeds" is the subject that the adjective is describing.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Juliet talks about the the steeds as being "fiery-footed". This highlights the speed of her horses.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
[Enter Juliet alone.]



Gallop apace...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Juliet is alone, and she begins speaking on the stage. This is an example of soliloquy, a speech delivered when a character is alone on the stage.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Juliet is alone on the stage, and she begins a speech. Keyword: alone.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: ...Towards Phoebus' lodging.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is an allusion - a reference to characters or events outside of the play itself. Phoebus, being a Greek god, was clearly not Shakespeare's invention.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Phoebus was the Greek god of the sun (also known as Apollo). This is a reference to a character outside of the play.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Come, night. Come, Romeo.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: By speaking to absent characters or non-human entities, this passage is a great example of apostrophe.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Juliet is speaking to people ("Romeo") and things ("night") that are not present or cannot answer her.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: ..Thou day in the night...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This is a paradox - opposites that cannot permit each other.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Day and night are opposites, and it is impossible for day to come in the night. This is contradictory and seemingly absurd.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: I saw the wound.... I saw it on his manly chest...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The Nurse's purpose in this play is mostly for comedic relief. This is a perfect example of comic relief.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Here, Juliet believes the Nurse is talking about Romeo being killed; in reality, she is referring to Tybalt dying on the streets. This is funny as the Nurse leads Juliet to assume that something terrible has happened when in reality, he is still fine.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Beautiful tyrant! Fiend angelical!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: These two oppositional ideas are played off each other and don't seem to make sense. "Beautiful" to describe a tyrant, and "angelical" to describe a fiend.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: A damnèd saint, an honorable villain.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: The adjectives describing the words don't work with the words themselves.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
There is no world without Verona walls

but purgatory, torture, hell itself.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Hyperbole is exaggeration, which is exactly what Romeo is doing here.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Romeo is exaggerating a little bit when he says that there's nothing except hell and torture because he's banished. Exaggeration has a literary device name... What is it?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Like a misbehaved and sullen wench,

Thou pouts upon thy fortune and thy love.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Because Friar Lawrence uses the word "like", this is a simile, not a metaphor.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Friar Lawrence compares Romeo to a "misbehaved and sullen wench", using the word "like".

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
...jocund day

stands tiptoe on the misty mountain-tops.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The day "stands" on mountains, which is a human ability. Days can't actually do this, which makes it personification.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Days cannot really stand, can they? This is giving them human abilities that they really don't have.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Then let me be ta'en; let me be put to death.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo will die. This is foreshadowing.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: We know from the prologue that Romeo is actually going to die. Shakespeare puts this quote here to remind the audience of this event which will happen later on.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: More light and light, more dark and dark our woes.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The similar structure ("light and light", then "dark and dark") and contrast marks this out to be antithesis.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Light and dark are contrasting elements, and there is also a contrasting idea with similar grammatical structure here.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Methinks I see thee, now thou art so low,

As one dead in the bottom of the tomb.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo will die, and here's another reminder! This is foreshadowing.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: We get more hints from Shakespeare about the fate of these characters. Juliet says this even though she doesn't have any idea what's going to happen, but we know. We know that Romeo dies.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: O Fortune, Fortune, all men call thee fickle.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Speaking to things that don't exist? A sure sign of apostrophe!
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Juliet addresses Fortune, who isn't actually an entity that most people can talk to.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Till I behold [Romeo]-dead-

is my heart.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: While her mom is talking about assassinating Romeo, Juliet says this. The pause allows for a double meaning: To her mom, she says that she wishes to see Romeo dead, but the pause also tells us that what's dead may actually be her heart. This double meaning is irony.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: While her mom is talking about killing Romeo, Juliet plays the good daughter and pretends to be OK with it. But we all know she isn't. Her words carry a double meaning.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
O, how my heart abhors

To hear him named and cannot come to him

To wreak the love I bore my cousin...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The double meaning that Juliet is aware of and purposefully uses makes this passage an example of irony.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: There is a double meaning of the word "wreak". It could mean both "give" (so in this case, "give love" to Romeo proportional to how much she loved her cousin), or "avenge" (as in to avenge her cousin's death).

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: O, God 'i'g'eden!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: "God 'i'g'eden" means "God give you good evening" (I know right?). Removing a bunch of letters between the words facilitates reading, which makes this elision. Not to be confused with syncope, which is removal of letters within only one word.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: There are so many abbreviations between words that nothing even makes sense anymore unless you knew what phrase he was speaking of.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Is there no pity sitting in the clouds...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Weather having feelings. This is a key trait of one literary device.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Venus was the Roman goddess of love (also known as Aphrodite in Greek mythology). This is an allusion.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Venus is not a character in this play. What is it called when authors make references to other literary works or mythical characters?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: I will confess to you that I love him.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Juliet, when referring to "him", is referring to her love for Romeo. This hidden double meaning is unknown to Paris, which makes this irony.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Paris and Juliet are engaged, and Juliet is saying that she loves "him". Who is "him"? Does this have a double meaning?

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: The roses in thy lips and cheeks shall fade...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Comparing Juliet's blush to roses in her lips and cheeks is a metaphor, since there isn't "like" or "as" in the text.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: There are not really roses in Juliet's lips and cheeks. Friar Lawrence is simply comparing them, but without comparison words.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
[Juliet, alone on the stage]

...God knows when we shall meet again.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: When a character is alone on the stage and they are speaking, it is a soliloquy.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Juliet speaks alone and delivers a long speech.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Death lies upon her like an untimely frost...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Capulet compares Juliet's death to an "untimely frost", using comparison words ("like").

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
...my child is dead

...my joyes are buried.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: The vowels in "dead" and "buried" are similar (they both make the "ed" sound), but they are not perfect rhymes. This is what assonance is.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: "Dead" and "buried" are almost a rhyme, but not quite.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: She's dead, deceased. She's dead, alack the day!
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: There are many "d"s at the beginning of "dead", "deceased", and "day", which emphasize each other.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Notice the first letter of these words.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Do you note me?
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Note means both a musical note, but also to pay attention to. This is an example of a pun.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Peter asks whether the musicians understand him (the literal definition of "note"), but he is also talking to musicians.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: I dreamt my lady came and found me dead...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: We know what happens to Romeo at the end of the play.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: ...As violently as hasty powder-fired...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: This comparison uses comparison words (i.e. "as... as..."), which makes it a simile.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: This comparison uses the structure "as... as...".

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Thou womb of death...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Womb is birth, yet here it describes death. This opposition is called...

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Death, that hath sucked honey out of thy breath...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Death cannot suck honey. It is not a person. (Hint hint)

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Beauty's ensign yet

Is crimson in thy lips and in thy cheeks.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: No comment available.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Romeo doesn't know the meaning of what he's saying. He sees crimson in Juliet's lips and cheeks, which means that she is about to wake up. The audience understands this, but Romeo doesn't.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: Here, shall I set up my everlasting rest...
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Romeo refers to death as "everlasting rest", which is a thing that is closely associated with death. This makes it metonymy.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Romeo is referring to death as "everlasting rest".

Romeo and Juliet.Quote:
Oh happy dagger,

...let me die.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Speaking to an item (such as a knife) is always an apostrophe.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: Juliet speaks to the knife, an inanimate item, that she is about to use and kill herself with.

Romeo and Juliet.Quote: The sun for sorrow will not show his head.
Romeo and Juliet.Comment: Weather and feelings usually indicate pathetic fallacy.
Romeo and Juliet.Hint: The Prince gives the sun feelings and the ability to act on its feelings. When speaking of weather, this is one type of personification.

Short Stories.Quote: They often feel like two halves of the same person.
Short Stories.Comment: No comment available.
Short Stories.Hint: This is a comparison, with the word "like".

Short Stories.Quote: Horse patooties.
Short Stories.Comment: This would not be acceptable in formal writing, such as an essay.
Short Stories.Hint: Is this formal written vocabulary? (It's not!)

Short Stories.Quote: I have been forced to take up psychological warfare.
Short Stories.Comment: Because this is exaggerating the relationship between Lucas and Amy, this is hyperbole.
Short Stories.Hint: Even if siblings often feel like they're in a "psychological war", they're usually blowing it out of proportion.

Short Stories.Quote: It was a heavy wet noise, like the sound of a big piece of raw meat being flung to the floow.
Short Stories.Comment: No comment available.
Short Stories.Hint: This is a comparison, with the word "like".

Short Stories.Quote: The peace-keeping forces are out at Mega-Foods doing the Saturday shop.
Short Stories.Comment: Because parents are being replaced by the word "peace-keepers", this is metonymy.
Short Stories.Hint: "The peace-keepers" refers to the parents, and "Saturday shop" refers to them doing shopping. What is substituting words for others called?

Short Stories.Quote: The carrot or the stick?
Short Stories.Comment: The carrot and the stick contrast each other (they're different methods of dealing with a situation).
Short Stories.Hint: The "carrot" and the "stick" are opposites put together for clarity.

Short Stories.Quote: The chocolate cheesecake or the Uzi?
Short Stories.Comment: These opposites create contrast.
Short Stories.Hint: The chocolate cake and the Uzi are very clearly opposite meanings and are put together for clarity and to emphasize each other.

Short Stories.Quote: I could try the chocolate cheesecake of bribery.
Short Stories.Comment: No comparison words = metaphor.
Short Stories.Hint: Amy compares "false bribery" to "chocolate cake", without any comparison words.

Short Stories.Quote: ...Lucas' sins, crimes, misdemeanors, and shady dealings.
Short Stories.Comment: Amy blows Lucas' actions out of proportion. This makes it hyperbole.
Short Stories.Hint: The worst things Lucas has done are bring a rabbit in the house and photocopy his bum. Are those as bad as "sins", "crimes", and "shady dealings"?

Short Stories.Quote: I am a stealth bomber with no aviation fuel.
Short Stories.Comment: A comparison with no comparison words is a metaphor. This has no comparison words.
Short Stories.Hint: Amy says she is a "stealth bomber with no aviation fuel". She is clearly not that - which makes this a comparison.

Short Stories.Quote: Not quite.
Short Stories.Comment: We know later that her "three figures" are an elaborate ruse to trick Lucas, and this sentence tells the reader of that (even if they don't pick up on it the first time).
Short Stories.Hint: Amy hints that she has nothing left up her sleeve, except for one thing. Right when the "three hooded figures" show up.

Short Stories.Quote: You're toast.
Short Stories.Comment: Informal language is colloquialism!
Short Stories.Hint: "You're toast" is informal language that would not be used in formal writing.

Short Stories.Quote: It rolls into the hall like a huge wave, breaking over my head, flowing into my mouth and nose until it becomes a taste.
Short Stories.Comment: Comparison with the word "like" is a simile.
Short Stories.Hint: Amy compares the smell of the strangers to water, using the structure "like...".

Short Stories.Quote: Very dramatic, Lady Macbeth.
Short Stories.Comment: Talking about characters outside of the story is allusion.
Short Stories.Hint: Lucas, for a knobhead, knows surprisingly much about Shakespeare's characters!

Short Stories.Quote: Each word is a little island of sound, a pebble dropped into a pool.
Short Stories.Comment: No comment available.
Short Stories.Hint: Amy compares words to a "pebble dropped in a pool", without using any comparison words.

Short Stories.Quote: R. L. Tankard is sitting on the back of the toilet.
Short Stories.Comment: No comment available.
Short Stories.Hint: "R. L. Tankard" refers to the book written by R. L. Tankard. This substitutes the book with the author, which is not part of the book.

Short Stories.Quote: Beep, beep, beep.
Short Stories.Comment: A sound transcribed into a word is an onomatopoeia.
Short Stories.Hint: This imitates the sound that the telephone makes.

Short Stories.Quote: She loved ... to feel—almost as a sunbather feels the sun...
Short Stories.Comment: No comment available.
Short Stories.Hint: Mary Maloney compares sitting with her husband to feeling like a sunbather, with the comparison word "as".

Short Stories.Quote: For God's sake.
Short Stories.Comment: This expression would be acceptable in everyday speech, but not in formal writing. This makes it a colloquialism.
Short Stories.Hint: Would you use this if you were to hand in an essay to for an English assignment?

Short Stories.Quote: The doc says his skull was smashed all to pieces just like from a sledgehammer.
Short Stories.Comment: No comment available.
Short Stories.Hint: One of the policemen compares the blow that killed Patrick Maloney to that of a sledgehammer, using the word "like".

Short Stories.Quote: Probably right under our very noses.
Short Stories.Comment: Because this is spoken by a character, who does not understand what he is saying, and the reader knows that the murder weapon (the lamb being eaten) is literally under their noses, this makes this example dramatic irony.
Short Stories.Hint: One of the police officers says this, speaking about the murder weapon. He does not know that it is literally "under [their] noses".

Short Stories.Quote: As boys they had thirsted for one another's blood...
Short Stories.Comment: Because this exaggerates the extend of the feud, it is an example of hyperbole. Because it also uses "thirsting for each other's blood" in a figurative way, this is also a metaphor.
Short Stories.Hint: As children, do they really "thirst" for each other's blood? Is this literal, or figurative? Also, is the extent of their feud really that deep?

Short Stories.Quote: Each had hate in his heart...
Short Stories.Comment: Because "had", "hate", and "heart" all start with the leter h, this is an example of alliteration.
Short Stories.Hint: Check out the first letter of these words.

Short Stories.Quote: A strange medley of pious thank-offerings and sharp curses...
Short Stories.Comment: This is both juxtaposition (the fact that the two are placed together), and contrast (the effect that this creates).
Short Stories.Hint: These two things ("thank-offerings" and "curses") are opposites of each other, yet they are placed very close to each other to emphasise the differences.

Short Stories.Quote: Other men, like Mr. Wills, can throw seed on the ground, scuff dirt over it, walk off and leave it, and have a crop of the prettiest, biggest melons you ever saw.
Short Stories.Comment: He's exaggerating about Mr. Wills' farming abilities. This makes it hyperbole.
Short Stories.Hint: Is this really a case or is the main character exaggerating a bit?

Short Stories.Quote: She was a wraith of a woman...
Short Stories.Comment: No comparison words = metaphor.
Short Stories.Hint: Mrs. Wills is being compared to a wraith (a ghost, i.e. she's very weak and unhealthy). Are there comparison words?

Short Stories.Quote: ...[Mrs. Wills was] pale as a button bean.
Short Stories.Comment: Comparison words (as... as...), so this is a simile.
Short Stories.Hint: The main character compares Mrs. Wills to being as pale as a butter-bean. Are there comparison words?

Short Stories.Quote: That big old moon sailed serenely overhead, climbing higher into the sky...
Short Stories.Comment: Giving human attributes to objects is personification; in this passage, the moon is given the ability to do human things like sailing and climbing.
Short Stories.Hint: This sentence makes the moon seem like it could be a human being ("sailed serenely", "climbing"...). What type of literary device gives things human attributes?

Short Stories.Quote: "Shucks ... he ain't got buckshot in that gun."
Short Stories.Comment: These words ("shucks", "ain't") are not formal words, and make this colloquialisms.
Short Stories.Hint: Would any of this pass in a formal writing assignment? I think not.

Short Stories.Quote: I could taste the sweet red juices oozing over my tongue, feel the delicate threaded redness of the heart as I squeezed the juices out of it.
Short Stories.Comment: The words that the author uses creates vivid imagery ("sweet red juices oozing over my tongue", "threaded redness", etc.).
Short Stories.Hint: What type of picture does this paint in your mind? Does the choice of words help you imagine what the protagonist is thinking about?

Short Stories.Quote: The meat muddied on the ground, the seed scattered.
Short Stories.Comment: The first alliteration starts with "m" ("meat", "muddied"). The second starts witht he letter "s" ("seed", "scattered").
Short Stories.Hint: Look at the first letters of the words.

Short Stories.Quote: It chilled me deep down ... like the cry of a wild animal.
Short Stories.Comment: No comment available.
Short Stories.Hint: Mr. Wills, upon having discovered the theft of the melon, gets super angry. The protagonist hears his scream of frustration and compares it with the word "like".

Short Stories.Quote: ...crying in such strength.
Short Stories.Comment: The fact that crying and strength are seemingy incongruous things makes this an oxymoron.
Short Stories.Hint: It seems oppositional in nature to have crying (which is a sign of weakness), as a sign of strength.

Short Stories.Quote: Mrs. Wills has been poorly all spring, and she dearly loves the taste of melon for eating... Every day she would ask me if the great seed melon was ready yet.
Short Stories.Comment: Feeling sad (or more speficially, pity) is pathos. Here, the thing Mr. Wills has been working for has been destroyed, and it wasn't a selfish thing either. Poor guy.
Short Stories.Hint: This passage is supposed to make you feel sorry for Mr. Wills. What is that type of literary device called?

Short Stories.Quote: ... looking down at the wanton waste we had made...
Short Stories.Comment: The alliteration in this passage serves to underline the "wanton waste" (the deliberate and unprovoked waste) that the protagonist wrought on the seed melon.
Short Stories.Hint: Check out the "w"s in this sentence.

Short Stories.Quote: Her eyes were smiling too.
Short Stories.Comment: By describing her eyes as "smiling", the author gives the eyes human abilities (i.e. to smile).
Short Stories.Hint: Eyes cannot smile. That would be creepy.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Old Marley was as dead as a doornail.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: This comparison uses comparison words, so it's a simile.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: A comparison is done between Marley's dead and a doornail, with the structure "as... as...".

A Christmas Carol.Quote: No warmth could warm, no wintry weather chill him.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: The repetition of the letter w makes this alliteration
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Look at the first letters ("warmth", "warm", "wintry", "weather".

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Gnawed and mumbled by the hungry cold...
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Allowing the cold to "gnaw" and "mumble" gives it human abilities. This is personification.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: The cold "gnaws" and "mumbles", which are actions that humans do.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: It had a dismal light about it... like a bad lobster in a dark cellar.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: No comment available.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: The word "like" is used in this comparison.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: There were Cains and Abels...
A Christmas Carol.Comment: When the author refers to characters or people who are not from that work, it is an allusion.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Cain and Abel is from the Bible.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: There's more of gravy than of grave about you, whatever you are!
A Christmas Carol.Comment: This wordplay between "gravy" and "grave" is a pun.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: "Gravy" and "grave" are used for comedic effect here, based on how the words are used.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: The crisp air laughed to hear it!
A Christmas Carol.Comment: "Laughing" is a human thing, and ascribing human abilities to non-human things (in this case, the air) is personification.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Can air laugh?

A Christmas Carol.Quote: There was an earthy savour in the air, a chilly bareness in the place...
A Christmas Carol.Comment: An "earthy savour" and "chilly bareness" are examples of imagery appealing to smell and touch. Imagery does not necessarily have to do with an "image"; it can be for any of the five senses.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: This passage contains description that appeals to the senses.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Poor Robin Crusoe...
A Christmas Carol.Comment: This reference makes this passage an example of allusion.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: "Robinson Crusoe" recounts the story of a guy who gets shipwrecked and separated from the rest of society. This is a reference to another work of fiction.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Nothing. There was a boy singing a Christmas Carol at my door last night. I should like to have given him something: that's all.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Feeling sorry for a character is the author creating pathos.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Scrooge begins to have a change of heart, regretting that he was not more generous. Considering his angry self before, this makes the readers feel a bit sorry for him.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: He has the power to render us happy or unhappy; to make our service light or burdensome; a pleasure or a toil.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Putting opposites next to each other creates contrast (it emphasizes the difference between the opposites).
A Christmas Carol.Hint: "Happy" and "unhappy" are opposites. "Light" and "burdensome" are opposites. "Pleasure" and "toil" are also opposites.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Heaped up on the floor, to form a kind of throne, were turkeys, geese, game, poultry, brawn, great joints of meat, sucking-pigs, long wreaths of sausages, mince-pies, plum-puddings, barrels of oysters, red-hot chestnuts, cherry-cheeked apples, juicy oranges, luscious pears, immense twelfth-cakes, and seething bowls of punch, that made the chamber dim with their delicious steam.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: How this scene is described creates imagery - with sight ("heaped upon the floor", "dim with delicious steam"), taste ("luscious pears" , etc.), and smell ("delicious steam").
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Look at these delicious adjectives! Does it make you feel anything?

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Scrooge the Baleful...
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Using this adjective highlights Scrooge's miserliness, which make this an example of epithet.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: The use of "baleful" highlights a particular personality trait of Scrooge's.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: If these shadows remain unaltered by the Future, the child will die.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Feeling sorry for a character (in this case, Tiny Tim), makes this an example of pathos.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: "The child" refers to Tiny Tim. He is the happiest child, even though he is very sick. This makes us empathize for him.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: I am sorry for him; I couldn't be angry with him if I tried. (Spoken by Scrooge's nephew)
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Two characters that are opposites make a character foil. They emphasize each other's worst qualities (Scrooge's selfishness) and best parts (forgiving nature of Scrooge's nephew).
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Scrooge is very mean Scrooge's nephew is not at all. These characters, that are so unlike each other, emphasize each other's character traits.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: This boy is Ignorance. This girl is Want.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: In this passage, Dickens compares these two desires (Ignorance and Want) to filthy children as a metaphor for what they really are.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Dickens gives us a representation of Ignorance and Want, was two disgusting children.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Oh cold, cold, rigid, dreadful Death, set up thine altar here, and dress it with such terrors as thou hast at thy command: for this is thy dominion!
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Speaking to ideas or concepts that are not human makes this an example of apostrophe.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Here, the author speaks to Death. However, death is not a person.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: "If there is any person in the town, who feels emotion caused by this man's death," said Scrooge quite agonised, "show that person to me, Spirit, I beseech you!"
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Feeling pity for somebody is a sign of pathos.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Scrooge expects the Ghost of Christmas Yet to Come to show him somebody who feels sad about his death. However, what we actually see is somebody who is thankful that he has died. We are supposed to feel sorry for this guy, who is having a change of heart already.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: I am as light as a feather, I am as happy as an angel, I am as merry as a schoolboy.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: This structure of comparison words is makes this an example of simile.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Scrooge compares himself to all of these, with the structure "as... as...".

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Clash, clang, hammer; ding, dong, bell.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Sound words (such as "clang", "clash", "ding", "dong") are examples of onomatopoiea.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: These words are transliterations of the sounds that bells make.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Tell 'em to bring it here.
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Because this abbreviation of the word is at the beginning and it makes it easier to say, it makes this an example of elision.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Scrooge is so excited that he takes out the "th" in "them", so he can speak faster.

A Christmas Carol.Quote: Thank'ee!
A Christmas Carol.Comment: Removing consonants and vowels between words is an example of elision.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Scrooge is very excited, and melds together the two words ("thank" and "you") to make "thank'ee".

A Christmas Carol.Quote: His own heart laughed...
A Christmas Carol.Comment: No comment available.
A Christmas Carol.Hint: Hearts cannot laugh, because that would feel really weird in your chest. This gives human abilities to a heart.
